title: brexit theresa may eu talks uk lead prime minister dominic raab michel barnier
story: Created with Sketch.Prime minister takes 'personal responsibility' for overseeing negotiating strategyClick to followIndy PoliticsTheresa May takes charge of EU talks and downgrades role of Brexit departmentTheresa May has told MPs she is taking&nbspcontrol of Brexit talks as she sliced off part of the Brexit department’s remit and passed it to Downing Street officials who report directly to her.In a statement published on the last day before parliament’s summer break, the prime minister said responsibility for negotiating Britain’s exit from the EU would pass from the Department for Exiting the European Union&nbsp(DExEU)&nbspto Downing Street’s Europe Unit, giving her greater control of&nbspthe process.Ms May said her team would assume control of the “preparation and conduct of the negotiations”, while her new Brexit secretary, Dominic Raab, will deputise for her during talks with Brussels.The move will&nbsphand greater influence to&nbspthe prime minister’s main Brexit adviser, Olly Robbins, who leads the Europe Unit and&nbsphas assumed increasing responsibility in recent months.The change prompted claims that Mr Raab&nbsphad&nbspbeen “sidelined” just days after he took over the role from David Davis.&nbspIn a written statement to MPs, Ms May&nbspsaid: “It is essential that in navigating the UK’s exit from the European Union, the government is organised in the most effective way. To that end I am making some changes to the ision of functions between the Department for Exiting the European Union&nbspand the Cabinet Office.“DExEU will continue to lead on all of the government’s preparations for Brexit: domestic preparations in both a deal and a no deal scenario, all of the necessary legislation, and preparations for the negotiations to implement the detail of the future framework. To support this, DExEU will recruit some new staff, and a number of Cabinet Office officials coordinating work on preparedness will move to DExEU while maintaining close ties with both departments.Ms May said that, from now on, Downing Street will&nbspassume responsibility “for the preparation and conduct of the negotiations”.She said: “I will lead the negotiations with the European Union, with the secretary of state for exiting the European Union deputising on my behalf. Both of us will be supported by the Cabinet Office Europe Unit and with this in mind the Europe Unit will have overall responsibility for the preparation and conduct of the negotiations, drawing upon support from DExEU and other departments as required.Some staff will move&nbspfrom the Brexit department to the Cabinet Office as part of the shakeup but&nbspthe total number of Brexit department staff&nbspwill not be cut, Ms May said.Brexit Resignation: July 10th 2018 Maria Caulfield MP Conservative Party's vice chair for women July 10th 2018Brexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conservative MP for Bolton West Chris Green MPBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conor Burns MP next to Boris JohnsonBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Steve Baker, EX-Minister at the Department for Exiting the European UnionBrexit Resignation: July 8th 2018 MP David Davis Ex-Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union Brexit Resignation: July 10th 2018 Maria Caulfield MP Conservative Party's vice chair for women July 10th 2018Brexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conservative MP for Bolton West Chris Green MPBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Conor Burns MP next to Boris JohnsonBrexit Resignation: July 9th 2018 Steve Baker, EX-Minister at the Department for Exiting the European UnionBrexit Resignation: July 8th 2018 MP David Davis Ex-Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union The change follows&nbspmonths of frosty relations between No 10 and the Brexit department, with Mr Davis having grown increasingly frustrated at the direction Mr Robbins was taking. Tory Brexiteers are suspicious of Mr Robbins, who they see as being a supporter of a soft Brexit, and&nbspare likely to raise concerns about him assuming a greater role at the expense of Mr Raab, a vocal Eurosceptic.&nbspThe move&nbspis also likely to be seen as a sign of mounting concern among Ms May’s team at the prospect of failing to secure&nbspa deal by the October deadline.&nbspAsked about the changes while giving evidence to the Commons Brexit committee, Mr Robbins said Mr Raab would continue to lead talks with Michel Barnier, the EU’s chief negotiator, but that Ms May considered the negotiating strategy to be her “personal responsibility”.May will keep UK under EU laws for another 21 monthsNo-deal Brexit will make it ‘illegal’ to pay pensions to retired BritsCriminals could go free because of ‘catastrophic’ Brexit security dealMr Raab, appearing before the same committee,&nbspadmitted there had been some “shifting of Whitehall deckchairs” but said he would continue to deputise for Ms May. The changes were designed to ensure there is a clear chain of command, he said.&nbspBut Labour claimed Mr Raab had been “sidelined” after just days in the job.Jenny Chapman, a shadow Brexit minister, said: “Dominic Raab has been sidelined by the prime minister before he has even had the chance to get his feet under the table.”Department for Exiting the European UnionEnter your email addressFill out this fieldor register with your social accountAlready have an account? title: ian paisley suspended dup expenses holiday sri lanka mp north antrim northern ireland
story: Created with Sketch.Theresa May's working majority on key votes reduced by one during 30-day suspensionClick to followIndy PoliticsMPs also backed a call to suspend Mr Paisley from the Commons for 30 daysIan Paisley has been suspended from the Democratic Unionist Party after he was found to have breached parliamentary rules over a luxury trip paid for by the Sri Lankan government.The decision by the DUP comes after MPs supported a punishment for Mr Paisley that recommended he be suspended for 30 sitting days.During his suspension, Theresa May will&nbspsee her working majority on key votes reduced by one as the party props up the prime minister's fragile government in the Commons through the supply and confidence arrangement.Arlene Foster’s speech to the LGBT+ community was tone deafUK abortion law 'more deadly than Holocaust', says ex-DUP ministerDUP leader threatens to withdraw support for May on Brexit customsThe DUP has backed itself into a corner with its reactionary viewsA DUP statement said: “The Officers of the Democratic Unionist Party have considered the report of the House of Commons Committee on Standards on Ian Paisley MP.“The party takes this report and the matters contained within it very seriously. The party officers have decided to suspend Mr Ian Paisley MP from membership of the party pending further investigation into his conduct.“The party does not intend to make any further comment on these matters during the course of the above outlined process.”The North Antrim MP earlier vowed to fight for his seat if he faces the electorate over his failure to declare two luxury family holidays paid for by the Sri Lankan government.In March 2014, the senior Democratic Unionist lobbied against a proposed United Nations resolution to investigate alleged human rights abuses during a civil war on the Indian Ocean island without citing his financial benefits.“In view of the seriousness of this matter, we recommend that Mr Paisley be suspended from the service of the House for a period of 30 sitting days starting on 4 September 2018,” said the Commons standards committee said last week.MPs on Tuesday backed the recommendation from the committee meaning the suspension from the chamber will now go ahead.Patrick Corrigan, head of Amnesty International in Northern Ireland, said the victims were those killed in Sri Lanka.“Mr Paisley saw fit to lobby the prime minister against a UN investigation into gross human rights violations, including the mass killing of civilians at the end of the Sri Lankan war, for which no adequate investigation has ever been carried out,” he said.Committee on StandardsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldor register with your social accountAlready have an account? title: pakistan election 2018 who win preview imran khan voting exit polls nawaz sharif pml pti
story: Created with Sketch.Since campaigning began, around 200 people –&nbspfour of them candidates –&nbsphave lost their lives in terrorist attacksClick to followThe Independent OnlinePakistani volunteers rush an injured person to a hospital following a suicide attack on an election rally in Peshawar on 10 JulyPakistan will make history on Wednesday when the country goes to the polls to elect a new government, the first time it will ever have achieved a second democratic transition of power in a row.Yet while that should be being hailed as an unprecedented landmark of stability for the nation, there are warning signs to be found in a campaign that has been one of the most dangerous and distasteful in modern history.With the ousted prime minister and former leader of one of the two main parties, Nawaz Sharif, in jail on corruption charges, the narrow favourite appears to be former cricket legend and playboy Imran Khan.From social media to the streets, the vicious nature of the campaign has polarised Pakistani society into supporters of Mr Khan’s Pakistan Tehreek Insaf (PTI) party, and the incumbent Pakistan Muslim League – Nawaz (PML-N) of Mr Sharif.But with the two main parties doing anything they can to sully each other’s reputations, it is also possible neither will prove popular enough to win outright. The left-leaning Pakistan People’s Party, led by the son of assassinated former leader Benazir Bhutto, should stand ready to play kingmaker in third place – but adding to the chaos, PPP has already ruled out a coalition with either main party.It has also been an exceptionally violent buildup to Wednesday’s vote. Since campaigning began, around 200 people – four of them candidates – have lost their lives in terrorist attacks.Mr Khan has painted himself as the change candidate, and used Mr Sharif’s jailing over the ownership of luxury property in London to frame PTI as the anti-corruption party.But he is also favoured by conservatives and the military, and Mr Sharif has accused the country’s immensely powerful generals of “pre-rigging” the election in PTI’s favour. He says they also had a hand in his conviction and 10-year sentence.Speaking to The Independent in Islamabad, PML-N central media coordinator Muhammad Mandi said the party was “ready for a landmark&nbspelection”. “Our workers are charged, our voters are ready to get out and vote and we issue a warning to the authorities concerned, that we will not tolerate any rigging.”Here’s what we can expect of Pakistan’s likely new leader, Imran KhanBlood appeal after 128 killed and hundreds injured in Pakistan bombingBomb blast in Pakistan kills at least 128 people ahead of electionCould Trump-Kim summit inspire a wave of other unlikely peace talks?Party members have been told to be “watchdogs” of the vote, casting their own ballots before going on to watch the process of counting and the retiring officers for any irregularities.Mr Mandi said the Pakistani nation had widely accepted Mr Sharif’s narrative of “respect the vote”, which paints the military, courts and conservative establishment as anti-democratic. “No one can stop the PML-N winning the general election on Wednesday,” he said.PTI’s spokeman Asad Umar claimed the party was ahead “in all opinion polls”. “On 25 July, the people of Pakistan will defeat the corrupt mafia and Imran Khan will be the new prime minister,” he said. Mr Umar described the rigging charges from PML-N as “baseless and nonsense”. “After the arrest of Nawaz Sharif they are nervous, and they want to make the election controversial,” he said.In a pre-election assessment report, an independent think tank called the Pakistan Institute of Legislative Development and Transparency (Pildat) said there was little doubt there had been attempts at what has been dubbed “pre-rigging”.According to its own modelling, the two parameters that have depreciated the most since Pakistan’s last election were the perception of neutrality of the military towards political parties and candidates, awarded the lowest score of 33.4 per cent, followed by the perception of freedom of private media from the influence of state institutions and vested interests, receiving a score of 37.8 per cent.Ahmed Bilal Mehboob, president of Pildat, said:&nbsp“It is a fact that all mainstream parties are complaining about pre-poll rigging, and the mainstream public are not happy with the way the election campaign has been run.“In the history of Pakistan we have not had many elections about which we can say they were free and fair,” he said. “Now we have to see whether the pre-election rigging will fulfil the objectives of the establishment of Pakistan, and what the fallout will be if it does not.The chief election commissioner (CEC), retired Justice Sardar Muhammad Raza, on Tuesday assured voters that the Election Commission of Pakistan (ECP) was “trying its best to hold free, fair and unbiased elections”.In a video message released by the election body, Mr Raza urged voters to fulfil their “duty towards the nation” by casting their votes calmly and responsibly on polling day.&nbspPolling begins at 8am local time, and concludes at 6pm. While one side or the other might claim victory as early as Wednesday night, official results could take up the three days to tally.&nbspTransgender in PakistanDancing at Shakeela's party, an event to Peshawar, PakistanThere are positive landmarks to be found aside from the flurry of recriminations. For the first time in history, five trans candidates will be standing for election, and there are also a record 171 women in the running, though they make a small minority of the 12,500 candidates vying for national and provincial seats across the country.Nonetheless, there will be a huge security presence trying to maintain order on the streets on Wednesday, with approximately 800,000 law enforcement and army personnel deployed.Of more than 85,000 polling stations across the country, around 17,000 have been declared “highly sensitive” and will receive special security measures.The majority of these – more than 11,000 – were in the populous Punjab and Sindh provinces, where the election is expected to be won or lost. Rights activists have also expressed concern that soldiers will be positioned inside booths where votes are cast.For Ayesha Siddiqa, a defence analyst and author of a book about the power and financial holdings of Pakistan’s military, the outlook is worrying. story: Created with Sketch.Web users were struck by tiny arachnid's bright orange and turquoise markingsClick to followThe Independent OnlineColour-blind scientist realises he has discovered a new species of spider only after posting pictures onlineA scientist discovered a new kind of dancing peacock spider&nbspbut did not realise until he posted photos online, and web users caught sight of its extraordinary colouring.Biologist Jurgen Otto is partially colour-blind, so when he spotted the tiny arachnid while out searching for a separate creature&nbsphe “didn’t think much of it” because it looked very similar to other kinds he had previously seen.He was combing an area of southern West Australia last autumn for examples of a different spider found by environmental consultant David Knowles, in 1994, when he came across the species he has now named&nbspMaratus unicup.The spider is just a few millimetres&nbspin size, and when performing its courtship dance it raises its third pair of legs and its brightly-coloured abdomen. Its orange and turquoise stripes have a striking symmetry.The name is derived from Lake Unicup, where it was found.“There was quite a reaction to photographs of it on the internet, with people saying it’s beautiful,” Dr Otto told&nbsp.World news in picturesA woman reacts as she tries to find her dog, following a wildfire at the village of Mati, near Athens, Greece. title: michael gove reintroduce beavers to countryside forest of dean
story: Beaver tree-clearing activity along streams and rivers also has the potential of reducing flood risk (Image: )British Beavers were hunted to oblivion in the late Middle Ages because of the high value of their rich, waterproof pelts and also precious scent glands used for creating perfumes.Yet it is their wood-gnawing activities of building dams and creating natural landscapes that sees them regarded today as &ldquokeystone species essential for restoring habitats and bolstering bioersity.Beaver tree-clearing activity along streams and rivers also has the potential of reducing flood risks.As the two beavers were released in their new 6.5hectare sanctuary at the start of a three-year project to assess their ecosystem benefits, Mr Gove said: &ldquoThe beaver has a special place in English heritage and the Forest of Dean.                Michael Gove PANICKED as he cancels event while May battles for future                &lsquoThey DESTROYED our fleet&rsquo Brexiteer lord SAVAGES EU fisheries policyThis release is a fantastic opportunity to develop our understanding of the potential impacts of reintroductions and help this iconic species, 400 years after it was driven to extinction.&ldquoThe project is an example of our wider approach to enhancing bioersity.It is another step towards our aim of leaving the environment in a better state for future generations.In another boost for beavers, Mr Gove also announced &pound20,000 funding for their trial reintroduction in Devon.In another boost for beavers, Mr Gove also announced &pound20,000 funding for their trial reintroduction. (Image: )Footage has already emerged of newborn beaver kits being carried by their parents along the county&rsquos River Otter.Conservationists hope the beaver release in Gloucestershire will herald legislation to combat the decline of British wildlife.Tony Juniper, Executive Director at WWF, said today &ldquoBringing back lost species like the beaver is an important step in reviving our natural environment.But if we are to halt the long-term decline of our wildlife and to begin the task of restoring what we have lost, then we urgently need an ambitious Environment Act backed up by a strong watchdog to hold the Government to account, which like a beaver needs to have sharp teeth.Historic records show how the Greathough Brook was once home to thriving populations of wildlife. (Image: )Beavers can make easy work of bringing down trees and saplings with their powerful rodent incisors, creating rich habitats by building dams and affecting the flow of water course.Birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, a host of invertebrates as well as plants can all benefit from beaver activities, while they are also effective in improving water quality and reducing flooding.Contrary to some misguided beliefs, beavers do not have a significant impact on forestry or agriculture and nor do they eat fish.The Forestry Commission first announced in March 2017 that it was hoping to trial a beaver reintroduction in the Forest of Dean&rsquos Greathough Brook and was subsequently granted a licence by English Nature to release the animals at a carefully chosen and secure site.Rebecca Wilson, head of planning and environment, West England Forest District, Forestry Commission, said: &ldquoBeavers are natural habitat engineers, restoring complex wetland habitats and providing habitat for declining species while slowing the flow of water downstream.&ldquoWe are delighted to welcome beavers to the Forest of Dean and are keen to observe the many benefits they will bring to both local communities and the wider Forest of Dean environment.Historic records show how the Greathough Brook was once home to thriving populations of scarce wildlife such as water vole, glow-worms as well as wood white and pearl-bordered fritillary butterflies, species depend on light, warm conditions that are no longer found with the decline in sheep grazing and shading from trees.The beaver trial will be used to identify how their dam-building can hold large volumes of water. (Image: SWNS)By clearing trees and damming watercourses, beavers will hopefully enhance patchworks of woodlands and wetlands to help increase the abundance of wildlife.From a human aspect, the nearby Gloucestershire village of Lydbrook, which has suffered several floods in recent years because of the high volumes of water flowing down the Greathough Brook, will also benefit.The beaver trial will be used to identify how their dam-building can hold large volumes of water and also control its slower flow downstream to prevent flooding.

title: legal working temperature uk heatwave uk weather forecast too hot to work
story: Matt Gingell, an employment lawyer, explains your rights.Employees are not expected to work in temperatures below 16C (or 13C if doing physically demanding work) but, surprisingly, there is no maximum legal temperature in the workplace.The Trade Unions Congress would like to see a change in the law to introduce a new maximum indoor temperature, set at 30C or 27C for those doing strenuous jobs.Employers usually have work dress codes and employees could be expected to follow the rules, whatever time of the year and regardless of the temperatures.Men may be required to wear suits and ties. Women may, for example, be required to wear formal skirts or dresses.                UK heatwave warning: Dog's BLISTERED paws serve as harsh reminder                UK HEATWAVE WARNING: London at risk of &lsquoCATASTROPHIC&rsquo fires as fire...What if an employee objects?Supposing an office does not have a cooling system and an employee refuses to wear a jacket and tie in the heat?Depending on the situation and the employer&rsquos rules, the employer could potentially send the employee home and take disciplinary action.However, if an employee was dismissed for refusing to wear a jacket and tie, provided the employee had two years&rsquo continuous service, the employee could bring an unfair dismissal claim.The Trade Unions Congress would like to set a new maximum indoor temperature. (Image: )It of course makes sense to relax dress codes in hot weather. (Image: )It is likely that an employment tribunal would find that a dismissal was outside the band of reasonable responses open to an employer - but of course each case would depend on the circumstances.Irrespective of the law, bosses need to take a practical approach.It of course makes sense to relax dress codes in hot weather.Bosses should also consider taking other steps to make things easier for their staff.Measures could include ensuring that employees have fans and offering flexible working so that staff can avoid travelling in the rush hour.Measures could include ensuring that employees have fans and offering flexible working. (Image: )For employees working outside, employers could provide sunscreen, water and breaks - and make sure that working patterns are arranged so that employees are not working in the middle of the day.It really is important to show flexibility.After all, a happy workforce is going to be a more productive workforce.Matt Gingell is a specialist employer lawyer in London.

title: pay rise public sector austerity liz truss commons
story: Urging critics to be more positive, Ms Truss hailed the rises as fantastic news for workers. (Image: )Treasury minister Liz Truss told the House of Commons: We are able to announce these pay rises only thanks to the hard work of the British people which has brought down the deficit by over three quarters and allowed us to reach the point where the debt will begin to fall this year.We didn't listen to the siren calls from Labour for damaging splurges, and that's why today we're able to scrap the cap and increase public sector pay.Public sector pay was frozen for two years from 2011 then capped at 1 per cent a year and unions have been arguing for rises closer to 5 per cent to make up for lost earnings.Urging critics to be more positive, Ms Truss hailed the rises as &ldquofantastic news for workers.                Queen&rsquos pay rise: Monarch's estate income increases to &pound20million                Public sector news: One million workers set to receive pay riseRejecting claims the rises will mean service and staff cuts, because unlike the previously announced deal for NHS workers including nurses and porters, the Treasury is not making new money available, she insisted Whitehall ministries can afford the increases from their existing budgets.Teachers in England will get rises of up to 3.5 per cent, with some allocated for leadership roles and schools deciding how it is set, worth between &pound800 and &pound1,366 a year.Schools will get &pound508 million extra from the central Department for Education to cover the increases.For other departments, the pay rises are being funded from savings.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the rises for doctors and dentists recognised their value. (Image: )Labour Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury Peter DowdMembers of the armed forces across the UK are awarded a 2 per cent annual rise.This is less than the 2.9 per cent recommended by their independent pay review body, but will be supplemented this year by a one-off 0.9 per cent to reflect the brilliant work they do for our country, said Ms Truss.It means the average soldier will get an extra &pound680 in annual pay, plus this year's bonus of &pound300.Prison workers in England and Wales will get at least a 2 per cent rise, plus a one-off 0.75 per cent payment, with extra for new recruits.Police in England and Wales get 2 per cent, raising average constables' pay to over &pound38,600 a year.Junior doctors, specialist doctors, GPs and dentists in England will get increases of at least 2 per cent, with 1.5 per cent or at least &pound1,150 a year for consultants.Ms Truss told the Commons the deals were &ldquoaffordable and responsible.But Labour Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury Peter Dowd protested: These proposals will do nothing to repair the damage done to our brilliant public sector workers by this Government&rsquos slash-and-burn policy in relation to public sector pay.Over the past seven years, our teachers have lost &pound2,500, our firefighters &pound3,000, our prison officers &pound4,000 and our paramedics &pound4,000 in real-terms pay cuts. Even the armed forces have been affected by this stingy Government.Junior doctors, specialist doctors, GPs and dentists in England will get increases of 2 per cent. (Image: )Yet the Government think it is enough to announce an uncosted proposal that will, at best, leave workers just about breaking even on their austerity-slashed pay, while civil servants and others continue to see their pay cut.This is a mendacious PR exercise.He said lack of new money to fund the rises would force cash strapped departments to make further cuts to services and staff numbers and what for? All so that the Prime Minister can get a cheap PR hit to try to cling on to power.Paul Whiteman, general secretary of the NAHT union said the Government had ignored pay review body advice to give all teachers and heads the same rise and the British Medical Association said doctors had been let down.The Institute for Fiscal Studies calculated that the increases will cost departments around &pound800m. (Image: )Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the rises for doctors and dentists recognised their value and dedication and took into account both affordability and the prioritising of patient care.From October, a consultant starting work in 2013 will have seen a 16.5 per cent increase in their basic pay, rising to a salary of &pound87,665 from &pound75,249, the Government noted.Education Secretary Damian Hinds said the rise for teachers would ensure the profession continues to be a competitively rewarded career, but he would do more to tackle issues like workload.The Institute for Fiscal Studies calculated that the increases will cost departments around &pound800million a year more than the 1 per cent pay rises previously planned for.The current public sector pay bill comes to around &pound180bilion a year, around 9 per cent of GDP and the second largest item of government spending after benefit and pension payments.

title: victorian memorabilia sewing machine sells for thousands at auction
story: It was made by Owen Robinson and Co at the Champion Works, Kettering, Northants. (Image: SWNS)It was made by Owen Robinson and Co at the Champion Works, Kettering, Northants., in the late 1800s and this model was manufactured from around 1874.The machine was expected to fetch around &pound60 when it went under the hammer at Hansons Auctioneers, Derbyshire, on Monday, but ended up selling for &pound2,000.Auctioneer Charles Hanson said: It's wonderful when forgotten items like this turn out to be sought-after treasures.This amazing result goes to show that an old sewing machine gathering dust at home could be worth a small fortune.                Collector stunned as &pound30 'fake' 17th century wine bottle fetches &pound21kNever dismiss an object that may have been in your family for years, or stuck in the loft, just because you think it's worthless - the opposite may be true.The Champion Sewing Machine Works began in Victoria Street, Kettering, in 1872 and was founded by Owen Robinson who was originally a silk weaver and clock repairer.Mr Hanson added: A thriving sewing machine manufacturing industry started in the UK around 1852.Many companies remained small and only made sewing machines for relatively short periods before disappearing.The Champion Sewing Machine Works began in Victoria Street, Kettering, in 1872. (Image: SWNS)The machine was expected to fetch &pound60 but instead sold for &pound2,000. (Image: SWNS)This sewing machine was clearly extra special, a humble part of Britain's manufacturing heritage.We understand these models were made from 1874, which means the item could be nearly 150 years old.It's small, sturdy and heavy and its name indicates it was made for household purposes.Sewing machines transformed lives, enabling people to make clothes much more quickly.We're proud to call the invention our own. The first working sewing machine was generally considered to be the work of Englishman Thomas Saint in 1790.

title: rare pound note collector auction glasgow
story: The rare Caledonian Banking Company Limited &pound1 note dates back to 1876. (Image: SWNS)The note, which originated in Inverness, Scottish Highlands, included the handwritten signatures of the accountant and manager, which is said to have increased its value.Sarah Cotter, head of jewellery, watches and coins at McTear's, said: It might seem surprising that a &pound1 note could be worth &pound1,700.But when it is as rare as this Caledonian Banking Company Limited one it was inevitable it would generate a lot of interest and demand from collectors around the world, even when not in perfect condition.                Victorian sewing machine dating back 144 years sells for THOUSANDSOur experience tells us that lots of old coins and banknotes are hidden at the back of drawers and cupboards so we always encourage people to have a quick look, just in case they have something valuable tucked away that they didn't know about.The note has strong connections with Inverness as the Caledonian Banking Company was established there as a joint-stock company, in 1838.

title: sandcastle competition mum pay entertainment licence
story: Sandcastles with a large bill attached... (Image: NC)Highland Council warned her that, in addition to the &pound559 licence, she&rsquod need to fill in a lengthy application form, provide formal first aid cover and explain fully how the event would affect other beach users.Dawn, 41, mother of&nbspfour-year-old Jessica, said she simply wanted to get a few families together on the beach at Nairn for some fun during the summer holidays.She said: &ldquoEverything for kids is so expensive, I thought we could have some old-fashioned fun on the beach and bring a few families together.&ldquoThe idea was for the kids to have an hour to make their sandcastles, they would all get stickers and we&rsquod get someone local to judge the best ones.Notice for Nairn residents (Image: NC)But Highland Council told her she would have to pay up and follow local authority protocol for the event.Dawn added: &ldquoI was panicking when I got the email through, thinking I might need to cancel it and the kids were already excited.&ldquoThere is too much red tape and so many barriers to get through to run an event, people will end up giving up.The event was saved by Fochabers firm Saltaire Security, which offered their services for free and provided a copy of their own public liability insurance certificate to Highland Council, which waived permission fees. There were also offers to provide lifeguard cover and Nairn Business Improvement District also came forward to say it would help.The event will now go ahead on Sunday with registration taking place from 10am at Nairn Links for categories ranging from pre-school to teenagers and adults.A council spokeswoman said a public entertainment licence was required for either indoor or outdoor premises for certain types of events.

title: fomo holiday photos cause jealousy envy unhappiness edinburgh university research
story: However, these &ldquonegative emotions prompt differing reactions among photo browsers according to their age, according to researchers from the University of Edinburgh.Older users &ndash those born before 1980 &ndash say that travel envy motivates them to book a holiday.Those born after 1980 &ndash are more likely to go on a &ldquodigital detox and cut down on their Facebook use.Younger users also report feeling motivated to do other things to make them happy, such as shopping online or revisiting their own snaps from previous holidays.                Adults spend more time on gadgets than they do sleeping                Could you survive a digital detox?The researchers analysed data from people between 18 and 70 years old.More than 800 users reported their reactions to seeing their Facebook friends&rsquo holiday posts in anonymous online surveys and telephone interviews.Female users said they were more likely to feel down afterwards because posts made them envious of friends spending time with partners or families.Male users, on the other hand, are more likely to report feeling sad because they are missing out on adventure and exploration.TripAdvisor have revealed the top 10 best all-inclusive resorts in Europe1 of 10The researchers from the Scottish university, working with others from Exeter, Falmouth, and Stockholm, say the findings show an unwelcome side effect of people comparing their own lives to others on social media.Dr Ben Marder, at the University of Edinburgh Business School, said: &ldquoThese findings help us understand the emotional and behavioural outcomes of viewing travel posts.&ldquoThey show how those somewhat idyllic posts by friends on social media are likely to make us feel sad in our own lives and take measures to make us feel happier.The study is published in the Journal of Travel Research.

title: roman greece discovery gold jewellery grave noblewoman
story: Greek archaeologists discovered jewellery in a grave belonging to a noblewoman (Image: REUTERS)Her name, according to a burial inscription, was Neko.The box-shaped grave was found untouched in the vault of the Episkopi monument, a rare burial memorial of the Roman era, which was later turned into a Byzantine church and a monastery.Golden wristbands, rings, a long golden necklace, a female figure carved cameo buckle, glass and metal vases and fragments of the dead woman's clothes were found in the grave.The well-preserved mausoleum on the tiny island, in the Cycladic group southeast of Athens, was likely to have been constructed to shelter the grave, archaeologists said.                What is the Antikythera mechanism? Google honours ancient computer                Travel in time to Ancient Greece by visiting IthacaDirector of the Ephorate of Antiquities of Cyclades Dimitris Athanassoulis said: We were unexpectedly lucky.This is Neko's mausoleum.It's very rare. A monument, one of the Aegean's most impressive, has got an identity.We now have the person for whom the building was built, we have her remains, her name.The grave was virtually intact  (Image: REUTERS)Archaeologists work over the grave of an ancient noble woman (Image: REUTERS)Despite attacks by grave robbers in ancient times and the building's various uses through the centuries, Neko's grave was found intact mainly because it was well hidden in a blind spot between two walls at the basement of the building, Mr Athanassoulis said.He said that experts thought Neko had links to the island but it was not clear whether she was actually from Sikinos.He said: We are now trying to find out more about her.We are still at the beginning.

title: diana would have known how to fix the meghan and thomas markle debacle
story: So many people have ­commented on the likeness between the late Princess Diana and Charlotte, the granddaughter she sadly never met.Diana often spoke of her desire for a daughter and she would have doted on Princess Charlotte.I can imagine proud Granny taking her to Disneyland and buying Princess outfits. She would have let Charlotte run riot in her bedroom, trying on all her designer clothes and shoes and raiding her make-up bag.It’s so tragic that all of these happy times were not to be. When William saw all of his children come into the world, most especially baby Charlotte, he must have felt the loss of his mother even more keenly.Diana would have been there with her arms full of presents, and not just for the babies. There would have been thoughtful gifts for Kate and lots of hugs and happy tears.You can well picture her ­giving newlywed Harry a cheeky nudge and telling him to “get on with it” so she could have more grandchildren to spoil.I also think that if Diana had still been alive this sad situation between Meghan Markle and her dad would never have been allowed to turn so toxic.Diana would have seen this potential problem looming even before the engagement was announced and nipped it firmly in the bud.She would have insisted and ensured he was invited to the UK and would have dispensed shrewd and invaluable advice on how to deal with all of the hoopla surrounding the wedding. Diana learned the hard way how to deal with the media and palace officials. She was misquoted, manipulated and misunderstood during her time as a royal wife and knew all the pitfalls and how to avoid them.Skittish Meghan would have been soothed and calmed and all of the bad feeling among the Markle family would have surely evaporated.Diana would have advised Meghan’s dad on his wedding suit, helped him with his speech and rehearsed him walking down the aisle.She would have put this rather shy and ordinary man completely at ease.Rather than watching his daughter getting married on TV while cowering in a cheap bed and breakfast in the US, he would have been an integral part of the happiest day of her life.Instead, we have a constant stream of ill-advised interviews given by Thomas where he appears to have been ignored and abandoned and, whether it’s fair or not, Meghan seems increasingly cold-hearted.Photos yesterday of. him celebrating his 74th birthday alone with just a fast food takeaway for company don’t exactly help, whether they were staged again or not.A present, phone call or card from Meghan would have gone a long way to build bridges.It’s all turning a tawdry soap opera meaning commentators such as Sharon Osbourne will keep the pot boiling.Just this week she inferred Thomas has a drink problem and should get clean, ensuring more lurid headlines and bad feeling as he furiously has to deny all of the allegations.No one is coming out of this well and never has Princess Diana been more missed.Harry needs her wise counsel and William knows what an important part she could have played in the lives of his ­children.I know her sons will never really get over her death, but I do hope when William looks into his daughter’s beautiful eyes he is heartened to see a reflection of his mum rather than finding it ­unbearably sad.THE way BBC News treated Cliff Richard was utterly shameful and I’m not in the least surprised it lost its court case.The poor man went through years of hell and became a virtual recluse – and his physical and mental health was profoundly affected.At a time when he should have been enjoying the rewards of a lifetime’s graft, he was enduring sleepless nights and often crying in anguish on the kitchen floor.Many in the media have expressed fear and disquiet that any sort of Cliff’s Law will mean restrictions on newspapers, radio and TV, and this is indeed troubling.But the blame should be pointed firmly at those who thought it was a good idea to send a helicopter to film and report an OTT police raid on an innocent man.Seeing Cliff outside the courtroom this week looking extremely fragile and on the verge of tears was heartbreaking.Clearly the sunny, friendly, optimistic Peter Pan of Pop has gone for good and in his place is a haggard, careworn, wary victim.Before the court case, Cliff told me he doesn’t have photos taken with fans and their children any more.It was painful to see the hurt and mistrust in his eyes.He then revealed this week that his VIP status meant he was allowed to use the secret Wimbledon tunnel under Centre Court and Court No1 to bounce quickly between both venues and view as much tennis as possible.Cliff doesn’t do that any more, and never will, because the tunnel goes past the ball boys’ changing area and he doesn’t want to put himself in a situation where he could potentially be accused of something unspeakable.I really hope that when enough time has passed he can get some of that old “glass half full” spirit back, but he will never be the person he was.And no one else should have to go through such a hideous ordeal when they have done nothing wrong.IF you don’t want to watch a movie that will make you laugh, cry and come out singing Abba songs, we can’t be friends.I thoroughly enjoyed Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again – a rare example of a sequel that is better than the original.The starry cast includes Meryl Streep, Julie Walters, PIerce Brosnan, Andy Garcia and Colin Firth. But the cherry on the icing on the cheesecake is the legend that is Cher.I was lucky enough to host the world premiere this week in London and had the chance to talk to the cast, who were effusive in their praise of Her Cherness.It was surprising to hear she STILL gets nervous before going on set and she was genuinely bewildered by all the love in the air for her.I thought one elderly gay gentleman was going to explode with happiness when Cher blew him a kiss.It was so endearing – and there is nothing more deliciously camp than Cher stepping out of a helicopter in a blonde wig and sequins before going on to sing Super Trouper. She’s a class act and a throughly lovely woman.WATCHING politicians squabble like ferrets in a sack soon loses its novelty value – and our eyes are now glazing over whenever the dreaded subject of Brexit rears its ugly head.But we should never forget that when we woke up the day after the referendum – to discover a majority had voted to leave the EU – there was NO actual plan.Bupkis. Nada. Zilch. Diddly-squat.There wasn’t even a “to do” list.Instead, all the rats deserted the sinking ship, claiming the dog had eaten their homework or a big boy did it and ran away – leaving the (female) PM to tidy up their reeking mess. Funny that.No matter which way you voted, surely we can all agree on one thing.There was little or no thought put into how to actually implement such a seismic change. Not even a few notes on the back of a fag packet.Now, two years down the line, the whole big, fat mess is farcical and beyond parody.As a nation, we are a laughing stock.Shame on all those careerists and fence-sitters for their arrogance, stupidity and downright mendacity in not having even a half-arsed plan in place.A parcel of rogues, right enough.IF you fancy a right good laugh at some silly, bonkers, hilarious fun and games, tune in to BBC1 today at 5.05pm for another helping of Wedding Day Winners with myself and Rob Beckett.One couple will actually get married at the end of the show and it’s all very lighthearted and joyful.DID Burberry REALLY need to make a bonfire of its overpriced designer swag and burn an eye-watering £28million worth of clothing and cosmetics?In line with other designer labels, the fashion house claims the move was to stop counterfeiters getting their hands on garments and using them to produce fakes.But surely that just doesn’t add up.If criminals want to reproduce any designer clothes or handbags, they can go into any shop and purchase something – or, even simpler, just order it online.Could Burberry not instead have the mother of all sales in aid of Help for Heroes, or for the homeless charity Centrepoint, or any number of deserving causes here and in the Third World?That £28million would have gone a hell of a long way to help those in need.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: karren brady prime minister legacy
story: Because . . . ’twas ever thus — right? Politics is a man’s world and, to many, women still feel like token visitors.Even when Tony Blair famously had 101 “babes” in his 1997 intake of MPs, only four of his Cabinet appointments were female.Here we are, 20 years later, and yes, we have a female Prime Minister but there is still a prevailing view that the Cabinet, in particular, belongs to men.Clearly there’s something profoundly wrong with that equation.Given that this country is made up, more or less equally, of men and women, things would undoubtedly be fairer, not to mention calmer, if more women were on board.So the big question is, why aren’t there?Things are better than they were. Since the 2017 election there are 208 women in the Commons, up from 191 in 2015.But there are still not enough and you don’t have to look far for reasons why that might be.Most women are put off by the environment and the culture and wonder why on earth they would want to put themselves within a country mile of either.Take Prime Minister’s Question Time, which appears to be a bunch of overgrown public school boys booing, jeering and jostling with each other in their bid to establish who is top dog.What woman in her right mind would choose to enter that fray?Then there are the practicalities. This week, Lib Dem MP Jo Swinson was “cheated” in a crunch Brexit vote by the breaking of her pairing pact.This is an arrangement where one MP agrees not to vote to cancel out the fact that another MP on the opposite side is unable to vote — in this case Swinson was at home with her three-week-old baby.The problem was, her pairing partner reneged on the deal and voted.Then there are the hours, which can be difficult if you have a family. Any woman would need a very understanding partner and family to do the job.Also, any MP is opening themselves up to the line of fire and a lot of personal criticism — which multiplies for female MPs.Some have to deal with endless comments and speculation about their appearance, as well as threats of rape and death on a regular basis. Just this week a man was arrested over abusive Facebook posts aimed at various female MPs.If it’s true voters are biased against women, any female has to be ten times as talented, determined and tenacious to get the job in the first place.It’s no wonder women are put off entering politics.But if we want true equality then more women need to go into Westminster and the culture needs to change.That is why I support the campaign group Women To Win and will be taking part in an event called The Voice Of Women In Politics.The idea is to try to encourage more women into Parliament, outlining some of the changes that need to take place to raise the number of female candidates.Getting more women into politics is a no brainer.Women tend to work collaboratively to solve problems whereas — in my experience — men are more likely to lock horns, point fingers and try to shout the loudest. All too often men are interested in progressing to be a leader, whereas women are more focused on getting the job done.And when women DO find their voice in politics, it can be very powerful, and they often hae the balls to say things that men just wouldn’t.Look at Tory minister Anna Soubry, who this week suggested the PM should take control of her hardliner MPs and stop pandering to the likes of Jacob Rees-Mogg.I know she’s got a lot on her plate at the moment, but if I was Theresa May I would be spending a good proportion of my time and energy on making real changes to politics in order, specifically, to attract many more women.It could be one of the greatest legacies she could hope for.Thomas Markle is a concerned dad who just wants to be reconnected with his daughter.Meanwhile this HALF-sister has turned a constant shade of green and wants to get involved in any way she can.Is it any wonder she wasn’t invited to the wedding?MY heroine of the week is 21-year-old Emilia Holden a waitress in Georgia, US, who was at the end of a shift when a customer casually grabbed her bottom as he walked past.Her response? She followed him, grabbed him and body slammed him to the ground, then called the police – after which he spent two nights in a police cell.What a fantastic response. Good for her.But also, who are these men that think that they can just grab a woman’s behind just because they want to?But hearing about elaborate plans by Pixie Lott which include a total of 18 bridesmaids all wearing the same dress, left me feeling a bit stressed out.Apart from anything else, it will take them all an hour to travel up the aisle.JAMES GODDARD-WATTS, the businessman whose family founded the hardware firm Screwfix, is still locked in a multi-million pound divorce battle with his ex-wife, Julia.They reached an agreement eight years ago ­– following the end of a 13-year marriage – that Mrs Goddard-Watts should get a £3.25million house and a £4million lump sum.But she complained that Mr Goddard-Watts had not revealed the full extent of his wealth at the time of the settlement and court fights began.Critics say Julia is a leech, greedy and after his money.But when you consider the worth and value of building a home, looking after children and a family while supporting a spouse, that should be worth at least half of whatever the partner who didn’t do all of that has earned in the meantime.So why shouldn’t she take him back to court?The law states that assets are divided equally.So people who hide theirs from their spouse only have themselves to blame if said spouse feels forced to take them to court to get what’s fair.ELLE Macpherson’s diet regime is enough to make me reach for the pizza delivery menu.The model is up at 5am. She has warm water, lemon and cayenne pepper.She has no booze, almost no carbs, no meat and no dairy. She is such a follower of the alkaline diet – based on the theory you can change the pH of your body through food – that she checks the acidity of her urine.I’m sure the diet is good for her – but who wants to add years to your life if those years are going to be so, well, dull?“The only chance I have of being on TV again is if I were very ugly,” he said.“I think only old, ugly women can get on TV. Like Mary Beard.”David added that he would only be hired now: “If I had tombstone teeth and rather funny hair and made a lot of noise about that fact.”Oh dear.Where even to start? When you resort to attacking someone’s appearance, you are in trouble.It’s not Mary Beard that has held back his career. It’s David himself.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: ayesha hazarika clusterfudge pm dishcloth leadership
story: The Tories are so busy plotting against each other they have forgotten there is a country to run.They have become a circular firing squad. Or a crap remake of Fight Club — except they DO talk about Fight Club. All the time.Theresa May has the leadership skills of a damp dishcloth, no authority and no political vision.A strong leader needs a clear mission. You may not agree with it, but you know what they stand for.“Live each day like it’s your last,” is our Prime Minister’s political strategy, except she’s not dancing in the rain.She is waiting for the sharks to circle. And soon they will come for her.Buffoon-in-chief Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg — a man so old-fashioned he could have been dug up by Time Team — wait to pounce. And Brexit is a mess. Things are so bad, even Elon Musk is out of ideas. No one will be happy with where we end up.And because there is no party political or Brexit majority in the Commons, politics is stuck, trapped in what feels like a never-ending Brexistential crisis.Normally, I’m with “Brenda From Bristol” when it comes to more elections and referendums.But maybe a People’s Vote on the final deal or another election is the only way to unblock Brexit.Think of it like a political plunger — unpleasant, nasty but necessary.You’d think the Opposition would be gleefully capitalising on all this chaos. Think again. Instead of going after the Tories, Labour has decided to traumatise the Jewish community. Again.Labour has had a horrible problem with anti-Semitism, yet instead of healing the wound, it has poured vinegar on it by choosing not to adopt the full International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance code of conduct.These guys sound pretty authoritative and the code is good enough for government departments and the Crown Prosecution Service.Many Jewish groups and leaders, including the Chief Rabbi, are distraught, confused and angry. And you can see why.This shameful decision led to an angry clash outside the Commons chamber where Jewish MP Margaret Hodge confronted Jeremy Corbyn, allegedly calling him an anti-Semite and a racist.Hodge lost family in the Holocaust and fought off the BNP in her Barking and Dagenham constituency.Instead of acknowledging her pain and offering to sit down with her, Team Corbyn are taking disciplinary action against her.I bet they deal with her far quicker than they did with Ken Livingstone, who couldn’t stop banging on about Hitler.What dark times for Labour, which once had a proud tradition of fighting racism. They must sort it out.Then we have the Lib Dems, who have proved useless. They have one policy — stop Brexit.Yet leader Vince Cable and ex-leader Tim Farron missed crucial votes on Monday. Talk about Dem and Dumber.To top it all off, the DUP’s Ian Paisley Jnr has been suspended for 30 days — which hasn’t happened since 1949 — for failing to declare lavish holidays to that well-known Northern Irish stakeholder, Sri Lanka.And to think Theresa May planned to give MPs an extra five days off as a reward for all their hard work.The country has had enough of these fools’ infighting, incompetence and filling their boots. Especially when we face so many big problems, from NHS funding to housing.Parliament’s end-of-term report is a big, fat fail. British politics should be taken into special measures.THE premiere of Mamma Mia! Here We Go Again was sun-kissed, frothy fun –  and no one mentioned the ­Customs Union. Bliss.The stars were out in full, including Cher. She is magnificent, but it is a little odd that at 72 she has fewer wrinkles than any other cast member, including 29-year-old Lily James. And the baby.She told Lorraine Kelly it was down to not drinking, smoking or doing drugs. Yeah, right.We women may be naive when it comes to the quest for eternal beauty, but we ain’t stupid.WHEN you hear of people getting up in the middle of the night and queuing, you think of the Boxing Day sales or the release of the latest Apple gadget.You don’t think of childcare.Yet more than 100 parents queued from 3am – armed with chairs, flasks and biscuits – trying to bag their child a coveted place in the breakfast club at a primary school in Cardiff.For many working parents, breakfast clubs are a lifeline.They can drop off the children in a safe environment where they can get a decent breakfast, then make it to work on time themselves.Though parents have the right to request flexible working hours, many fear the sack if they come in late.These spaces were limited and dished out on a first-come, first-served basis, which is why the parents took such drastic measures.This shows how desperate parents are for childcare that matches their working hours.The scrapping of Labour’s extended school programme and the first real-terms cuts to schools mean all these extras that were provided are no longer affordable.Childcare isn’t a luxury.It’s a necessity for millions of families and they are crying out for more breakfast and after-school clubs.JEFF BEZOS, the boss of Amazon, is a man clearly in his “Prime”.He’s now the richest man in modern history.Good for him.I’m all for celebrating entrepreneurs and hard work – but shouldn’t that apply to his poor workers toiling away in his warehouses?They would probably give Amazon working conditions zero stars.I wish our business leaders remembered some of their forefathers, who felt a moral and civic responsibility to look after their employees and took some pride in that.It makes business sense too. Happy workers are better workers.So after Bezos pops open the champagne, maybe he could spare a thought for his staff, who told an undercover reporter they pee in bottles because the loos are too far away and they are afraid of being accused of time-wasting.C’mon, Jeff – that’s really taking the p**s. ONE school in Liverpool had to apologise after kids as young as four were left in tears when they were denied an ice cream treat because they didn’t have a 97 per cent attendance record.How mean is that? What if they were ill? And surely it’s the parents’ fault.CARERS got another kick in the teeth this week when the Court of Appeal overturned a decision that those doing sleep-in shifts should earn at least the minimum wage.If the decision had gone through, it would have cost the UK care sector billions – so charities and local governments were relieved.But it shows what a raw deal carers get.Judges said only hours spent awake counted as work – but that is completely out of touch with the reality of what carers do.Many of the elderly and vulnerable people they look after need their help through the night, whether it’s a trip to the loo, to take medication or dealing with more serious situations such as seizures. Carers can’t exactly fall into a deep sleep. They have to be alert and listening in case they are needed.The rooms they sleep in may not be comfortable and they will be away from their own families.Many carers are paid so little that they live hand to mouth and barely get by.When I met a group in the West Midlands, they told me they couldn’t afford to put the heating on in winter and had to take their kids to the grandparents’ for tea once or twice a week just so they would be fed.Some were struggling so much they had to visit food banks.But they also loved their jobs and took great pride in looking after their clients as if they were family.They get paid a pittance, with some earning just £30 for a ten-hour shift.These low-paid workers – the majority of whom are women – are unsung heroes and deserve more.New Health Secretary Matt Hancock must make social care a priority and enforce minimum-wage law properly.It’s time we took better care of our carers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dr sarah wollaston column save lives
story: It is a crime which blights the lives of victims and can cause devastating psychological and physical harm.And it is a crime that also costs lives, with a significant risk of escalation to murder.The statistics are alarming.In a 2017 study by the University of Gloucestershire, based on 358 criminal homicides, stalking behaviour was identified in the run-up to 94 PER CENT of the murders.And stalking is getting easier. The spread of social media and other online communication, with its inherent anonymity, has only increased the misery for victims.But the speed of change has not been matched by a more robust framework to deal with it.Yes, we have tougher sentences — the Government was absolutely right to last year double jail terms for the worst cases from five to ten years.But progress has been too slow in recognising these crimes.In 2016-17, fewer than 1,000 prosecutions were commenced under stalking legislation.It was horrifying to read the account of Nicola Roberts from Girls Aloud yesterday.She told how she faced a barrage of more than 3,000 texts over five years from an ex-boyfriend, including threats to stab and burn her.Soon after being handed a lifetime restraining order, her ex began following her on Instagram.He “wanted me to know he was still watching me”, she said, chillingly.And yet the CPS saw no realistic chance of a successful prosecution for stalking because the social media activity was not taken sufficiently seriously, despite the obvious impact on Nicola’s life.As she put it: “I should be able to move on from an unhealthy relationship if I want and that’s not been able to happen.”She wants change — and she is right to.These kinds of messages leave you in fear for your life — feeling that someone is watching or following you is immensely distressing.A bunch of flowers is not a romantic gesture when sent by a stalker but a reminder that your persecutor is still watching and can still reach you.Stalking is a crime of obsession and fixation and it needs to be stopped before it becomes deeply ingrained.No legislation will be effective unless it is accompanied by training at the front line of policing and across the wider courts system.Victims must have the confidence to come forward at an earlier stage, for all forms of stalking to be recognised for what they are. It is my intention to make this happen.My Stalking Protection Bill will introduce so-called Stalking Protection Orders (SPOs) to help fill some of the gaps in the law.It will allow the police to act more quickly and to protect victims of so-called stranger stalking, where the stalker is not a former partner.Importantly, it will also take the onus off the victim to have to take action, as is currently the case for stranger stalking. At present many victims are left unprotected because they have to put protective measures in place for themselves, such as applying for a civil injunction to restrain someone from harassing them.Needless to say, many victims find this such a daunting task — not to mention expensive and time-consuming — that they end up not going through with it.If passed, the Stalking Protection Bill would allow the police to apply for an SPO through the magistrates’ courts on behalf of victims.Orders will require the civil standard of proof “on the balance of probabilities” but breach of an order would be a criminal offence, punishable in the most serious cases by a term of up to five years in prison.SPOs could set out requirements prohibiting certain behaviours, such as contacting the victim either directly or indirectly.It would be able to prohibit behaviours such as driving past the victim’s house, harassing friends, colleagues or family members, going within a certain distance of the victim or following them online.It could also set out so called positive requirements, such as attending a psychiatric assessment.In this digital age, the law would cover online contact from abroad and require that any IT equipment would be free from encryption, so perpetrators could not cover their tracks.Unlike the now-abandoned Police Information Notices, SPOs will have teeth, as they would be enforceable and breaching the terms of an order would have consequences.SPOs would also require stalkers to register all the names they use, as well as their address.While SPOs will provide better early intervention to protect victims, they are not intended to replace full prosecution for an offence of stalking.They will, however, enable police to better protect the safety of victims while gathering the full evidence for the CPS to prosecute a full stalking case.The Bill has almost completed its Commons journey but will not now return to the Chamber until late November.When the case for change is so pressing, and the Bill is backed by members across the House, I believe the Government should bring forward the final Commons stage so we can get on with delivering this vital change to the law — which will help to save lives.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk heatwave window left open increase burglaries
story: Crooks have been quick to cotton on in the hot conditions and are sneaking into homes and offices to help themselves, Thames Valley Police say.Cops have reported a surge in raids where thieves treated the heat as an open invitation to line their pockets.And in Oxfordshire theres been a leap in house raids where entry was through an open window or door.One case in Risinghurst saw thieves simply stroll in through an open door, walk into the living room and steal a handbag containing bank cards and cash.A similar raid on a house in Sherwood Place, Barton, saw the theft of a purse and money.Acting Inspector Neil Applegarth, who is in charge of neighbourhood policing for Oxford, said The opportunist threat definitely increases in the summer and the threat of burglars taking advantage of unlocked or open door and windows also increases.Burglary is a horrific thing. For everybody who gets burgled it is just miserable.But he warned the criminals Typically weve got a good idea who our burglars are because theyre often repeat offenders and they fit a certain demographic and lifestyle.They often specialise, in a criminal sense, in burglary. They often have a particular MO.In my experience we tend to catch burglars in the end. They manage to do a number of burglaries and then they get caught and we can link them back.They leave all sorts of marks in all sorts of ways and eventually we catch up with them.His officers are urging people to ensure that doors and windows stay closed - and locked if the householders go out.

title: moment a blonde jogger was caught pooing at the back of a wine shop during her morning run
story: CCTV images show the blonde woman yanking down her leggings, squatting and relieving herself for a full minute at the rear of the wine store.She is then seen pulling out a roll of toilet paper before dropping it on the ground and casually strolling off.Jim Shwilk, owner of Porter’s Liquor in Pyrmont, Sydney, said he initially thought a large dog was responsible for the mess left in the courtyard.But after checking his CCTV footage, he was shocked to discover the culprit was a blonde jogger.Jim, 61, said last Tuesday’s “deposit” wasn’t the first he’d noticed.He explained:  “The situation is certainly awful. Around ten days ago we came across a rather large deposit at the rear of the shop.“I put it down to a bad experience and thought someone had let their dog do it. I thought it must have been a large dog that wasn’t feeling very well.“On Tuesday morning, I had an appointment to attend and as I left the shop I was met by yet another large deposit.“Because we were unsure of why this kept happening and who was allowing it, we decided to check the CCTV footage to see what was going on.“You can imagine our shock and dismay to discover what we have now seen.”Jim claims he hasn’t released the footage to “harm or shame” the woman, but to warn her not to return.He added: “I have never seen the woman before and she isn’t a customer of ours.“She was around mid-twenties, a jogger and wearing a rucksack.“I was more than prepared to give her the benefit of the doubt. I suspect she was caught short.“Once is unfortunate, twice is a coincidence but I really don’t want a third time.“I wanted to release the footage purely as a deterrent. If this was to happen again, I will be forced to hand the footage over to the authorities.“We don’t wish them any harm or shame but we do wish that they cease using our rear lane as a point of relief as it is particularly distasteful having to clean up the remains.”

title: elton john hugs prince harry at aids conference evoking memories of stars charity work with royals mum diana
story: The Duke of Sussex is following in the footsteps of his mother in the fight against AIDS in recent years, raising awareness about HIV/AIDS and encouraging people to get tested.Harrys charity, Sentebale, focuses on supporting HIV-positive young people in the African nations of Lesotho and Botswana.The Prince introduced Sir Elton, who performed at his wedding reception, as he launched the billion-dollar MenStar Coalition at an international Aids conference in Amsterdam.The 33-year-old praised the star for campaigning to eradicate the disease.Sir Elton said more work is needed to being young men into the fold as a solution to end the scourge of the HIV virus, which is growing among certain groups.Sir Elton told the delegates: If we want to end Aids once and for all, we must make men part of the solution.It is time there was a global coalition to teach men to protect themselves, and in doing so it will teach them to better protect not only their wives and girlfriends, their sisters and daughters, but also critically their brothers and sons.The project will begin in Africa next year, where men across the continent will be encouraged to self-test for HIV, in a bid to empower them to seek treatment if positive and help stop the spread of the virus.Sir Elton said recent research had shown that men aged 24-35 were tested and treated for the HIV virus at unacceptably low rates.He added: We must find ways to change this. Too often, and for good reason, men have been seen as the problem in the fight against Aids.So in response we have done so much to safeguard women and girls, and rightly so, but we cant solve the whole problem if were only addressing half the situation.If we want to end Aids once and for all, we must make men part of the solution.Today Harry praised the work that had already been done to tackle the virus and support those who are HIV positive, but warned there is still more to do.He told the session on Monday morning: For over a quarter (of a) century, Elton has worked tirelessly to fund research and services in communities around the world.And today he has come to Amsterdam to announce his latest endeavour - a billion dollar global partnership to break the cycle of male transmission of HIV, particularly in sub-Saharan Africa.We stand here at a moment when the progress we have fought so hard for is at risk from a dangerous complacency.Too many around the world are still ignoring the damaging knock-on effect on education and other community services from not prioritising HIV prevention and treatment.This is a time when new, energetic and innovative solutions are needed more than ever before – and that is exactly what you are about to see from Elton and the Men Star Coalition partners.Yesterday the duke joined a session at the conference where youth delegates from countries including India, Zimbabwe and the US spoke about how Aids has affected their lives.At the end they all gathered for a group picture and Harry even posed for a selfie with one of them.Sir Elton John and Princess Diana first met in the 1980s and became close friends. In the years leading up to her death, they worked closely with each other to help destigmatise Aids by spreading awareness about the disease.In 1987, the Peoples Princess touched the unnamed man without wearing gloves, challenging the previously believed notion the disease could be passed via skin-to-skin contact. She was the first member of the Royal Family to touch someone with AIDS.She was quoted as saying: HIV does not make people dangerous to know. You can shake their hands and give them a hug. Heaven knows they need it.Diana was a patron of the National Aids Trust at the time of her death in 1997.Earlier this year, Sir Elton delivered the Diana Princess of Wales Lecture on HIV in her memory and the star continues to praise Princess Diana for using her royal status to normalise AIDS.Since her death, Sir Elton has continued to work relentlessly to fund research and services across the globe.(Words by Aisling Finn)Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may hosts welcome party in downing street for british divers who saved thai football boys from cave
story: More than a dozen dive experts and support staff joined the PM at a reception in 10 Downing Street.Mrs May paid tribute to their bravery in risking their lives to rescue the divers and their football coach on the amazing rescue mission earlier this month.Those attending the event included Robert Harper, John Volanthen, Christopher Jewell, Connor Roe and Joshua Bratchley and Vern Unsworth.Mr Unsworth was recently locked in a public battle with Elon Musk, after the tech tycoon wrongly accused him of being a paedophile.The divers and support staff posed with Mrs May and Thai ambassador Pisanu Suvanajata outside the famous black door of Number 10.Speaking during the event, the PM said: This was an amazing rescue mission.On hearing about the boys who were trapped most people would have just stood by but you chose to go out there and do something about it.The eyes of the world were on you and I think I can speak for everyone when I say a huge thank you. John, you have said that you’re not heroes - well to most of us, you are.Sadly we know that a Thai diver, Saman Kunan, died during this mission. He lost his life saving the lives of others – a danger you also faced.The Thai PM has written to me to say thank you for the fantastic job you did and I know that everyone in this country would agree. We are all very proud of you.”Mr Volanthen said: “It was an honour to join the incredible effort to rescue of these boys and their coach, and I would like to personally add particular reference to the skill and dedication of the many military groups and civilians we worked alongside, especially the Thai Navy Seals.“I would also like to extend my thoughts to the family of Saman Kunan.”The group joined the rescue efforts after being called in by Thailands Navy Seals.They were forced to find their way through flooded caves to find the patch of dry land where the 12 boys were huddling.The dangers of the expedition were highlighted when diver Saman Kunan died during the rescue attempt.But miraculously, the British-led team managed to get every one of the kids and their coach out of the complex, and theyre all on track to make a full recovery.

title: theresa may brexit negotiations remainer coup
story: The Prime Minister announced she was taking personal control of the talks with the EU, boosting the role of her controversial Brexit guru Olly Robbins.And she confirmed The Sun’s revelation last week that Mr Robbins was to harvest almost 100 staff from the Department for the Exiting the EU and bring them under his command at the Cabinet Office’s secretive Europe Unit.Mr Robbins will have overall responsibility for the preparation and conduct of the negotiations leaving new Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab in charge of getting the country ready for all exit scenarios - including No Deal.Mr Raab will step up preparations for leaving the EU next year without a deal in place by replacing his lost staff with new emergency planning officials.He attempted to dismiss the power grab as “moving the Whitehall deck chairs” but admitted there had been tensions between Mr Robbins and his predecessor David Davis.But former Brexit Department Chief of Staff Stewart Jackson branded it a “long predicted defenestration” that was a “transfer of power to the unaccountable Cabinet Office Europe Unit and hard core Remainers.”In a rare public appearance Mr Robbins rejected claims of a “coup detat” and insisted that he had not secretly gone behind the back of Mr Davis and forced his walk out.However the powerful mandarin admitted that Mrs May had tasked him with drawing up secret alternative plans two weeks before the crunch Cabinet showdown earlier this month at Chequers.Appearing at the Commons Brexit committee, Mr Robbins insisted that he had not sidelined Mr Davis or torn up the Brexit departments own Brexit blueprint, rather the position had “evolved”.However when confronted by MPs that Mr Davis had directly contradicted his version of events, the civil service high flyer would only shrug.Mr Jackson had accused Mr Robbins of running shadow, parallel operation and keeping officials and ministers from the Brexit department in the dark about the Chequers plan.But the civil servant hit back at  claims the plans were secret - insisting he had the full blessing of the PM to look at different options. He said: There was never a second secret White Paper” but “ministers had a series of papers before them”He insisted “there was not sudden twist in the road where one White Paper was done away with and another was written.”Tory Brexiteer Craig Mackinlay said: “Quietly somewhere was  a coup detat going on.”Labours Shadow Brexit Minister Jenny Chapman said: Dominic Raab has been sidelined by the prime minister before he has even had the chance to get his feet under the table.When Mrs May became Prime Minister in 2016 she promised that the negotiations with Brussels would be led by a Brexiteer.She said: I will create a new department responsible for conducting Britain’s negotiation with the EU.It will be led by a senior Secretary of State – and I will make sure that the position is taken by an MP who campaigned for Britain to leave the EU. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
