title: london tube temperature heatwave uk weather cattle
story: Images from camera firm FLIR showed stifling conditions on the Central Line amid the ongoing record-breaking heatwave.While above ground temperatures are hitting an already sweltering 34C, recordings on the Underground showed it was nearly 10C hotter, breaching EU regulations for moving livestock.Transport for London said: “We understand travelling can be uncomfortable.There are air conditioned trains serving 40 per cent of the network.Customers should ensure they have water with them and contact a staff member if they feel ill.”Officials are now urging bosses to let staff have a lie in to avoid the rush hour heat.The Trade Unions Congress (TUC) has also suggested that some workers should be allowed to wear vests as the heatwave continues.It said staff should be allowed “frequent breaks” and the opportunity to leave their ties at home.The TUC added: “Giving workers the choice of coming in earlier or staying late will let them avoid the sweltering conditions of the rush hour commute.”General Secretary Frances OGrady, said: “The most simple way for staff to keep cool inside when it’s scorching outside is being able to work in more casual clothing.“While shorts and vest tops may not be appropriate for all, nobody should be made to wilt in the heat for the sake of keeping up appearances.“And bosses who provide a cool and comfortable work environment are going to get more out of their staff.The shocking findings come as shops run out of fans and sun-seekers defy health warnings to soak up the super-strength sun-rays.Yesterday was the hottest day of the year as temperatures reached 33.3C in Santon Downham in Suffolk.And it is set to get even hotter, with temperatures expected to peak on Thursday and Friday.On the Argos site, at least five of its most popular fans are in “limited stock” while Wilko has completely sold out of its £35 fan.Becky Mitchell, Met Office meteorologist, said temperatures of 35C were forecast for Thursday in East Anglia and London, adding: Theres potential it could go even warmer than that.She said the climbing temperatures are due to warm air coming up from France combined with high pressure across the country.A respite from the heat could come by the end of the week, when thunderstorms are expected in eastern areas.An amber heat health watch warning has been issued for parts of England.The amber, or level three, warning is issued when temperatures are predicted to hit 30C (86F) during the day, and 15C (59F) at night, for at least two consecutive days.

title: python snake shed spot picture
story: Somewhere among the boxes, Nerf guns and blankets is a terrifying 2.5metre long python  -but can YOU spot her?Snake experts were called in Coolum in Queensland, Australia earlier this month after the stunned owner found the reptile cooling off inside.Max Jackson, from Sunshine Coast Snake Catchers 24/7, posted a picture of the snake after attending the call-out.He wrote on Facebook: Spot the Snake!There is a 2-2.5m Carpet Python hiding in this outdoor Coolum shed .... let’s see if you can find him!Users struggled to spot the slithery character.Many guessed it was running along the roof - wrongly.In fact, the lisping predator is coiled up to the left of the picture, under two black boxes.Carpet pythons often crawl into sheds and loft spaces during the cooler months to hide out.They are native to Australia, Papa New Guinea Indonesia, and the Solomon Islands.The reptiles can grow to four-metres in length, but despite their hefty size are not poisonous and dont pose any threat to humans.They eat birds, bats, lizards and small mammals - using their constricting powers to suffocate their pray.Still a shock to find during a ssssspring clean.

title: theresa may no deal brexit sun says
story: If that’s the case then surely we won’t be conceding any more to Brussels.The evidence on Friday — when the EU slapped down Theresa May’s Chequers offers — suggests otherwise.Hammond’s disparaging remark shows that Remainers are at the heart of Theresa May’s Government, running the show at the expense of Leave voices.This Government sees Brexit as a damage-limitation exercise rather than a golden opportunity for Britain to reinvent itself as a global and buccaneering free nation.How can we ever achieve Brexit in full if the Government itself is so institutionally Euro-phile? We need more Brexiteers at the heart of the project.Meanwhile, it is clear that the PM’s Chequers plan has not only failed to win over Brussels, but also her party. The grassroots are livid.It was as generous an offer as Mrs May could politically have tabled. Every time we are reasonable in our approach, the EU slaps us down. They are determined to punish us.We can’t just keep giving while the EU arrogantly takes. Enough is enough.It is clear Mrs May needs to change her approach to Brexit - and fast.The PM has repeatedly said: “No deal is better than a bad deal”.She must be true to her words — and properly start planning for such a scenario.BRITAIN is in the midst of a jobs boom.But you wouldn’t think it listening to all the Remoaner doom and gloom.Project Fear claimed more than 800,000 jobs could go within two years of a Leave vote.Instead, 610,000 have been added.That shows the continuing resilience of our country and strength of our economy.It is also testament to the resolve of hard-working, ordinary Brits who roll up their sleeves and get on with it.Shame our politicians seem incapable of doing the same.THIS is the weekend of traffic hell as families make their escapes for the summer holidays.But the sun is shining and schools are out so there’s plenty to be cheerful about.There is also a free bottle of Tetley’s Super Squash with your favourite newspaper today.Summer is always better with The Sun on Sunday.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kevin cash oxfordshire mansion for sale bankrupt
story: Kevin Cash, who created an empire across the world, has put his beloved Grade-II listed country pile on the market after being declared insolvent last Friday.North Aston Hall, near Bicester in Oxfordshire, boasts 11 bedrooms, an orangery, a roof terrace and a wine cellar.It also has a mile-long drive, landscaped gardens set in 194 acres and a riverside treehouse.The Mail Online reports how Birmingham-born businessman Cash became a millionaire in his 20s.He is reported to have had properties all over the world after amassing an estimated £500million fortune.The 54-year-old lived in the plush home with fourth wife Carla and their two children - as well as owning a £10million home overlooking Regents Park.The mansion was built in the late 1700s by renowned architect John Yenn.But he was declared bankrupt at Oxford County Court last week after he was found liable for fraudulent misrepresentation.A case brought by his butler and housekeeper, who unsuccessfully claimed to have been unfairly dismissed, heard how Cash would blow £50,000 a month on groceries.He went broke as a teen but clawed his way back and went on to make millions after starting his career selling frozen food.Cash then started buying up prime London properties and investing in internet firms - including the Bluestar property group, which buys and sells London residences.But he now owes more than £40million to creditors, with HMRC estimating he owes £13million in unpaid tax.The Mail Online reports the property is said to be owned by the Rose Trust, established by Cash’s parents, Barry and Sheila.This means it is not one of his personal assets like his Regents Park home, which has been seized by the bank.The mansion has its own leisure complex with a swimming pool tennis court and billiards room.There is a spiral staircase winding up from the hallway and French windows looking out onto the lawns from the dining area.The mansion was built in the late 1700s by renowned architect John Yenn.It was remodelled in the middle of the 19th century.There are two farm buildings in the grounds and four guest houses, making 30 bedrooms in total.

title: best and worst motorway service stations in england revealed
story: Many users complained that there were not enough parking spaces for lorries, with reviewers warning that the car park is a "free for all", "quickly becoming a nightmare" and "an accident waiting to happen".Transport Focus surveyed 9,600 customers for their opinion on factors such as toilets, staffing and food at 111 service areas in England between February and April.Toddington southbound on the M1 in Bedfordshire was given the second-lowest ranking with a score of 72%, followed by Southwaite northbound on the M6 in Cumbria (80%), Newport Pagnell southbound on the M1 in Buckinghamshire (81%) and Bridgwater on the M5 in Somerset (81%).Moto, which operates four of the five lowest-ranked services, said "major redevelopment works" at Thurrock and Toddington southbound "had a negative impact on our customers' perceptions".Meanwhile, the best-rated service station in England was Norton Canes on the M6 toll in Staffordshire, which earned a score of 100%.This was ahead of 10 services scoring 99%, including Wetherby on the A1(M) in West Yorkshire, Pease Pottage on the M23 in West Sussex and Woodall southbound on the M1 in South Yorkshire.Using Sky News' interactive vote below, have your say on whether you agree with England's worst motorway services by choosing your least favourite.     :: The results of this vote are not representative of the general population. title: coup claims as theresa may sidelines brexit secretary dominic raab and boosts top official
story: News of Mrs May's statement was delivered as both Mr Raab and Mr Robbins gave evidence to the House of Commons Brexit committee on Tuesday.The pair presented a united front, with Mr Raab insisting there was "no tension" between him and Mr Robbins despite "some shifting of the Whitehall deckchairs".The Brexit secretary revealed he was made aware of the shake-up in a conversation with Mrs May when he took on the role, as he stressed his department had not been "downgraded" and there was "one team" handling Brexit.Mr Robbins denied claims he had written a Brexit plan in "secret" ahead of a Chequers awayday for cabinet ministers, at which they agreed on the prime minister's proposals."There was never a second secret white paper," he said. Ex-Brexit secretary David Davis, who resigned in protest at the Chequers plan and was said to have a turbulent relationship with Mr Robbins, has claimed his former department was working on alternative proposals but they were never presented to ministers.The Brexit secretary told MPs he could not give a "precise moment" at which it might be clear the UK is leaving the EU without a deal, while he addressed claims there are plans to stockpile food in such a scenario."It would be wrong to describe it as the government doing stockpiling," he said."What we will make sure - and of course the idea that we only get food imports into this country from one continent is not appropriate - but we will look at this issue in the round and make sure that there is adequate food supply."One of Mr Raab's answers was greeted with laughter when he mistakenly told MPs the government "will do nothing that will draw a customs border down the Red Sea".Despite correcting himself to say the "Irish Sea", Mr Raab failed to give a similar guarantee that there would be no "regulatory border" between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK after Brexit.

title: is all what it seems with public sector pay rise
story: Since last year's snap general election, a number of Conservative MPs have openly suggested they believe the squeeze on public sector pay contributed to the party's failure to win an outright majority.Far from fixing the roof when the sun is shining, the scrapping of the pay cap is more akin to the government trying to find cover from the scorching heat of the public sector anger and criticism to which it has been exposed.The removal of the pay cap has been in gestation since the autumn, but the culmination of that process on Tuesday is unlikely to see that anger dissipate.Although teachers will receive a pay boost of 3.5%, that remains well below the 5% increase that unions have been demanding."The offers we're hearing about fall far short of the expectations of the union's negotiating position so I'll be surprised if it meant there was no successful strike ballots as a result of this," said GMB spokesman Andy Prendergast.That said, the increase in teacher pay is above the rate of inflation - currently running at 2.3% based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI). Labour have argued any pay increase that is not above the rate of inflation amounts to a real-terms pay cut - not exactly something that screams "good news".So no surprise that pay bumps for the armed forces (2.9%) and prison officers (2.75%) are being described by the Treasury as being "well-above inflation".But pick apart those figures and the claim seems a little misleading.But Labour's shadow chief secretary to the Treasury, Peter Dowd, dismissed the announcement as "a mendacious PR exercise".Another point of contention is how these pay increases will be paid for.In March, it was announced that some NHS workers, such as nurses, were to receive a 6.5% average pay increase over the next three years.But, that came with a pledge of extra money from the Treasury. Tuesday's announcements do not - they will come from existing departmental budgets.The government insists most departments will be able to meet the extra costs by diverting funds from budget underspends elsewhere, and in doing so will ensure the rewards are "sustainable without an increasing burden of debt being passed onto future generations".As she spoke in the Commons, Ms Truss was met with jeers from the opposition benches.Labour MPs stood up to raise concerns that lack of additional funding would lead to cuts to public services and redundancies down the line.

title: london foreign exchange sees record turnover
story: That has caused traders to dump sterling on various occasions.And even the European Central Bank has begun to hint at interest rate rises - although most people expect it first to begin unwinding the &#83642.4tn (&#1632.1tn) worth of asset purchases it made from 2015 onwards to stimulate the Eurozone economy.So volatility and, accordingly, FX volumes are picking up.Other factors include growing concerns over a global trade war - the Chinese yuan is currently trading at its lowest level against the dollar for more than a year and dollar-yuan trading in London has almost doubled during the past year - more political turmoil in the Eurozone, notably in Italy, as well as volatility in emerging market currencies.It will have come as a welcome relief to all of the big global investment banks which, as volatility declined, saw the profitability of their operations in FICC (Fixed Income [bonds], Currencies & Commodities) eroded.These are now picking up again.Analysis by Reuters of the latest results from Wall Street's big five - Morgan Stanley, Citi, JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs and Bank of America - reveals that during the first six months of the year, revenues from market trading across FICC and equities were up 10% on the same period last year.The bad news for them is that much of the take-off in volumes was during the first three months of the year, when volatility was more pronounced, with FX markets less hectic since then.The Bank's data also provides some interesting insights into what is being traded. Fibre accounted for 28.5% of daily FX volumes in April, down from 29.4% in October, while Cable's share of trading volumes rose from 12.5% to 12.9% - reflecting the swings in the pound.Perhaps reflecting events in the Korean peninsula, there was also a rise in trading in the dollar and the South Korean won, while US dollar-Canadian dollar business also picked up.Some people will decry the rise in volumes and deride it as nothing more than speculation.Well, yes, some of it undoubtedly is speculation.

title: pakistan election ex cricket star imran khan could be prime minister
story: His main opponent, the three-time former prime minister Nawaz Sharif, was arrested on corruption charges when he landed in Lahore from London earlier this month.He is now campaigning from prison in Islamabad and is reported to be suffering from health issues.In his place as candidate for the centre-right Pakistan Muslim League is his brother Shahbaz Sharif. The party have said they have been "victimised" but remain "resilient" and have seen "a spike in popular support".The all-powerful military has been accused of influencing the election in Imran Khan's favour by censoring news coverage.   Some believe it would suit the army to have a prime minister with only a thin majority, therefore giving them power behind-the-scenes.He is the son of former prime minister Benazir Bhutto, who was assassinated in 2007.His father is Asif Ali Zadari, who served as the 11th president of Pakistan.Whoever wins the election will need to seek an alliance with Bhutto's party or possibly a collection of independents.Voting day is a public holiday in Pakistan. Some 3,459 candidates, representing more than 100 political parties, are competing for 272 seats in the national assembly.Sixty seats are reserved for women while 10 have been kept aside for religious minorities including Hindus.

title: defence chiefs cancel plan build
story: NewsDefence chiefs cancel plan to build new Royal Navy warships after only one company bids for contractExperts warned the budget for designing and building a brand new warship was too low - and just one firm was able to make a viable bid&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor18:45, 24 JUL 2018News13 Duke-class frigates are being retired and replaced with just eight Type 26 Global Combat Ships (pictured) (Image: Publicity Picture)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPlans for new Royal Navy warships were plunged into disarray today after defence chiefs were forced to ditch a high-profile project. The Type 31e light frigate was trumpeted by ministers as a cheap replacement for an ageing fleet of anti-submarine vessels. Thirteen, Type 23, Duke-class frigates are being retired and replaced by just eight Type 26 Global Combat Ships. Ministers hoped to make up the shortfall in the Senior Service with five, &pound250million smaller ships which they branded the Type 31e. The “e” highlighted their hope to export it to allies. But experts warned the budget for designing and building a brand new warship was too low - and just one firm was able to make a viable bid.  Now, the Ministry of Defence has been forced to relaunch the competition to create a ship. But the &pound250million budget will stay the same. A spokeswoman insisted: “There have been no changes in our plans to procure a first batch of five new Type 31e frigates to grow our Royal Navy. “We still want the first ship delivered by 2023 and are confident that industry will meet the challenge of providing them for the price tag we’ve set. “This is an early contract in a wider procurement process, and we will incorporate the lessons learned and begin again as soon as possible so the programme can continue at pace.” While officials refused to reveal details of the bids received, citing commercial sensitivity, it is understood just one came in at the &pound250million limit. Sources said the single bid made an “effective and robust competition” impossible.

title: jeremy corbyn backs calls 5
story: NewsJeremy Corbyn backs calls for 5% public sector pay rise as Tories reveal lower than inflation increasesIt comes as the NHS reports a crisis in nursing recruitment and schools are struggling to hire and retain teachers&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent15:41, 24 JUL 2018News (Image: Birmingham Mail)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailJeremy Corbyn has backed union calls for a 5% increase in public sector pay after the Tory Government backed a cap which is less than inflation. The Labour leader hit out at plans for an average 2% pay rise for nurses, teachers and other workers without proper funding saying that this would likely lead to further cuts in the already struggling NHS and education sector. Speaking in Birmingham Mr Corbyn promised that a Labour Government would back wage rises of 5% as suggested by unions. He said: On the public sector pay cap, the government has said it's going to lift the pay cap the reality is that they're lifting the pay cap it's going to be an increase that's below the rate of inflation and it's going to be about 0.8% below it and the unions have said 5% is what is needed for it and we support that. But we also from what we understand there's no increase in funding for that so by increasing pay by 0.8% less than inflation that can only be paid for by cuts to public services.  Public sector workers saw their pay frozen from 2010 and then capped at 1% - far below inflation. It comes as the NHS reports a crisis in nursing recruitment and schools are struggling to hire and retain teachers. Speaking at EEF Technology's apprenticeship college in Aston, Mr Corbyn said: I think public sector workers have been very badly treated since austerity came in in 2010. He promised to fund a pay rise through overall tax changes and an increase in corporation tax. Most of public sector workers will see their salaries rise under the rate of inflation, measured at 2.4% under the Consumer Price Index (CPI).

title: moment tory brexit secretary interrupted
story: NewsMoment Tory Brexit Secretary is interrupted by news of his own demotionThe jingle of the Sky News phone app alert could be heard as Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab faced questions from the Commons Brexit Committee&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByDan BloomPolitical reporter16:18, 24 JUL 2018Updated17:14, 24 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWestminster aped TV farce The Thick Of It today after a Tory minister appears to have been interrupted at a hearing - by news of his own demotion. The jingle of the Sky News phone app alert could be heard faintly as Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab faced questions from the Commons Brexit Committee. The only Sky News app alert received in the same 10-minute period by this reporter stated: Theresa May announces she will lead negotiations to leave the EU, sidelining new Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab. It came after the Prime Minister announced she is taking personal control of talks with Brussels - two years after Britain voted to leave. Mr Raab, who insisted he knew about the statement in advance, voted Leave and was appointed to his Cabinet job two weeks ago when David Davis resigned.  But now Mrs May has announced she'll lead talks with Brussels herself, and Mr Raab will be her deputy. Mrs May said: The Department for Exiting the EU will continue to lead on all of the Government’s preparations for Brexit: domestic preparations in both a deal and a no deal scenario, all of the necessary legislation, and preparations for the negotiations to implement the detail of the Future Framework. I will lead the negotiations with the European Union, with the Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union deputising on my behalf.

title: caf owning boat captain kicks
story: NewsCafé owning boat captain 'kicks mum off vessel because of her crying baby'Steph Shaddick, had gone to the the floating Café Onboard in Devon, with her two children Barney, one, and Nancy, five, before being asked to move outside&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAlex RichardsSports writer22:11, 24 JUL 2018NewsSteph Shaddick says she was forced off the floating cafe (Image: DevonLive/ WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA caf&eacute owning boat captain who claims to have had enough of 'poor parenting' is claimed to have kicked a mum off his vessel because of her crying baby. Steph Shaddick, had gone to the floating Caf&eacute Onboard in Devon, with her two children Barney, one, and Nancy, five. She claims she was forced outside when Barney, who was crying loudly, became distressed. Captain and caf&eacute owner Robert Hunter defended his decision saying he had asked the 30-year old to take her baby to the outside seating area after he screamed 'for around 15 to 20 minutes' next to a queue of 20 hungry diners. He claims Steph was sat on her mobile phone rather than calming the child down - and that he is sick of mum's letting children run riot.  But the shocked mum said she was treated badly when she was made to carry a pram, a child, drinks and two meals through the crowded business, reports Devon Live .   Steph said the experience was some of the worst customer service she had ever witnessed. She explained: We went for chips on the boat, and when my youngest went to eat them they were too hot and he cried. There were a lot of foreign exchange students queuing up for ice creams at the time. The owner asked to 'take that screaming baby outside, this is not working for me.' He made us go outside with our cups, the pram and food. I had to manoeuvre through the students and had to sit on the side of a table outside. I felt like I had been pushed out. She added: He was just generally rude. He pointed outside and told us to go out very unpolitely, my baby wasn't being bad until then - it was just that he wanted the food. I have never had an experience in a business like this before. They are meant to be family friendly, there's a sign which says so, and its next to one of the biggest parks in North Devon.  Captain Hunter, who has run the cafe for around four and a half years ago, says he has 'put his life and soul into it.' Now he says he has 'had enough' with poor parenting on his family-friendly floating caf&eacute and even has a sign which reads: No barking dogs, no screaming kids and no loud mobile phones.' He explained: We had a mum come in and the baby was already crying while strapped into the pram. He was very close to the counter and the screaming got louder. It continued screaming and two people stood and asked my wife at the counter to do something about it. But we said it is up to the mother to do something. Then a queue began to form at the counter right next to the pram. The baby went ballistic at all these tall people towering over him. The mum did absolutely nothing, she was more focused on her mobile phone - she should have unstrapped him and carried him around. The screaming was so loud we could not hear what people wanted at the counter - the kid just go worse as he was overheated and distressed.

story: NewsClaims 'vultures' are targeting air passengers for 'share of payouts for travel delays'Firms are offering to handle delay claims for a share of up to 40% of passengers' compensation&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByNada Farhoud21:28, 24 JUL 2018NewsClaims firms are swooping on air travellers affected by delays to get a share of compensation for flight delays (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailClaims firms are swooping on air travellers to get a share of compensation for flight delays. Martyn James, of the Resolver complaints service, said: “Claims vultures are desperately circling, looking for another quick way they can snatch your compensation for doing nothing.”

title: company lets staff take unlimited
story: NewsCompany lets staff take unlimited holiday - and it's had a surprising affect on the businessGradTouch, in Manchester's Northern Quarter, are pioneering a new way to work&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience WriterLucy Roue16:34, 24 JUL 2018NewsJoe Twigg and Zac Williams co-founded GradTouch (Image: MEN WS)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMost of us dream of exploring the world and trying new things in exciting new locations. But unfortunately there are two big things which get in the way - money and work. While we can't fix the money part, there's a company in Manchester which is helping its staff out with the work bit.  Recruitment start-up GradTouch has taken flexible working to a whole new level and is now offering staff unlimited annual leave, reports the Manchester Evening News .  And bosses have found it's having a really positive impact on their business, which is now growing faster than every.  Last year the average amount of holiday taken by their 22-strong team staff totted up to 46 days. Co-founder Zac Williams explains: We're huge believers in having a great company culture and we're pioneering a new way to work. We don't have set hours in our contracts, instead employees agree to focus only on results. We have an unlimited holiday policy and we encourage our staff to work from wherever they want, whenever they want. This includes the freedom to work from home or trendy coffee shops and only pop into the Northern Quarter HQ when they are required at meetings. The 29-year-old continues: It's not something that works for everyone. You have to be comfortable with autonomy and you have to be self-motivated to work in that system.  We got rid of contracted hours so all it says is that staff will do what needs to be done to get the job done - but in more legal language. In order for us to build this business we needed to hire people that are better than us and let them get on with their jobs. If you hire properly then you can build a culture based on empowerment and trust. Zac and co-founder Joe Twigg introduced the policy two years ago after a gruelling investment round which brought in &pound500,000. Zac said: Williams said: We were building the platform as quick as we could and a lot of people were doing really long hours.

title: huge dinosaur foot measuring more
story: NewsHuge dinosaur foot measuring more than three-feet wide belonged to 'one of the biggest beasts to walk in North America'The bones belonged to a plant-eating animal similar to the Brachiosaurus, star of the film Jurassic Park, scientists have confirmed&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMartin BagotHealth and Science Correspondent21:24, 24 JUL 2018NewsScientist poses with excavated dino foot (Image: Getty)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA dinosaur's foot measuring more than three-feet wide is the largest found to date. The bones belonged to a plant-eating animal similar to the Brachiosaurus, star of the film Jurassic Park, scientists confirmed today. It comes from the sauropod family of dinosaurs, which had long necks and tails and were the largest animals to roam the earth. “Bigfoot”, found near Mount Rushmore, confirms brachiosaurs lived over a huge swathe of North America, from eastern Utah to northwestern Wyoming, 150 million years ago. Study co-author Dr Emanuel Tschopp, of the American Museum of Natural History, said: “This is surprising. Many other sauropod dinosaurs seem to have inhabited smaller areas during that time.  “There are tracks and incomplete skeletons from Australia and Argentina that seem to be from even bigger animals, but found without feet. “This beast was clearly one of the biggest that ever walked in North America.” The foot was excavated in 1998 but has been the subject of study for 20 years. The findings were published yesterday in PeerJ journal. Researchers from the US, Switzerland and Germany used 3D scanning to help compare the specimen to feet from different dinosaur species.

title: inside disused pub landlord 40
story: NewsInside disused pub where landlord let 40 people live in "appalling" conditionsHayden Rogers let out the Old Quay House pub in Flintshire, allowing 40 people to reside there with electrical faults, overloaded sockets, missing smoke and heat detectors and poor heating&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByMarc Waddington18:27, 24 JUL 2018NewsUp to 40 people were found to be living in the The Old Quay House pub at Connah's Quay (Image: Daily Post Wales)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA landlord who let up to 40 people live in “appalling” conditions at a disused pub has been hit with almost &pound16,000 in fines. Hayden Rogers let out the Old Quay House pub in Flintshire, allowing 40 people to reside there with electrical faults, overloaded sockets, missing smoke and heat detectors and poor heating. Fire escapes were also deemed inadequate and extinguishers were out of date.  Last year, an inspection saw the tenants removed from the pub, which the council said was “unsafe”.   Rogers was prosecuted by Flintshire Council, who said the property was in an appalling condition, reports the Daily Post .   The defendant didn’t turn up to court and the case went ahead without him.  Rogers was convicted of not having a house in multiple occupation (HMO) licence, and fined &pound2,000 after being found guilty in his absence.  He was found guilty of 11 breaches of the regulations, racking up a &pound1,000 fine per offence.  With Flintshire council and the court’s costs, he ended up with a bill of &pound15,633.

title: kate middleton something incredible prince
story: NewsKate Middleton did something incredible for Prince George the day after she gave birth to his little brother LouisKate Middleton gave birth to her third child, Prince Louis, in April - but she was determined to keep things as normal as she could for her other children Prince George and Princess Charlotte&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByZoe ForseyAudience Writer15:55, 24 JUL 2018Updated22:45, 24 JUL 2018NewsVideo LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeSee our privacy noticeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new arrival is a huge change for any family, and it can sometimes be hard for children to accept the new crying baby which is taking up all of mum and dad's attention. One of the things kids can find particularly difficult is the disrupted routine which inevitably comes with a newborn. But most parents do whatever they can to keep life as stable for their children as they can, and it appears the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge are no exception. In fact, it turns out Kate did something pretty incredible for Prince George the day after she gave birth to his little brother Louis.
